title: 114_s2327
content: The "Foster EITC Act of 2015" is the short title for this Act, which includes a permanent extension of modifications to the Earned Income Tax Credit. The "Foster EITC Act of 2015" includes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, such as increasing the credit percentage for families with 3 or more children and raising the income threshold for joint returns. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the credit amount from $3,000 to $5,000 and make inflation adjustments for the calendar year 2008. A conforming amendment removes paragraph (3) of section 32(b). These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2014. The Earned Income Tax Credit is being strengthened by increasing the credit amount to $5,000 and making inflation adjustments for the calendar year 2008. This amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2014. The Earned Income Tax Credit is being enhanced by raising the credit amount for individuals with no qualifying children to $8,820 and $10,425. Inflation adjustments are also being made to ensure the credit keeps pace with rising costs. The Earned Income Tax Credit is being enhanced by increasing the credit amount for individuals with no children to $8,820 and $10,425. Additionally, adjustments are made to the Internal Revenue Code to update the table and eligibility age for certain individuals. Lowering eligibility age for childless individuals and youth formerly in foster care by amending the Internal Revenue Code to change the age requirement to 21 (or 18 for youth formerly in foster care). The term "youth formerly in foster care" is defined as an individual who was in foster care at 16 years of age or older. Additionally, adjustments are made for returns relating to youth in foster care. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to lower the age requirement to 21 (or 18 for youth formerly in foster care) and make adjustments for returns related to youth in foster care. "SEC. 6050X. RETURNS RELATING TO YOUTH IN FOSTER CARE." Any State, local, or tribal agency responsible for reporting data to the Adoption and Foster Care Analysis and Reporting System must submit a return for individuals in foster care aged 16 or older. Once a return is made for an individual, subsequent returns may not be required unless specified by the Secretary. The return must be in the form and manner prescribed by the Secretary. The return for individuals in foster care aged 16 or older must include the name, date of birth, TIN, and other prescribed information. The person making the return must provide a statement to each individual as required. Every person required to make a return under subsection (a) must provide a written statement to each individual with their name, address, phone number, and required information by January 31 of the following year. Penalties may apply for non-compliance. The IRS requires written statements to be provided to individuals by January 31 of the following year for returns under subsection (a). Penalties may apply for non-compliance, including those related to youth in foster care. Sec. 6050X requires returns for youth in foster care. Amendments effective for taxable years after December 31, 2014. Section 4 simplifies the Earned Income Tax Credit. Modification of Abandoned Spouse Rule under Section 32(c)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for married individuals living apart with a qualifying child for more than half of the taxable year and not sharing the same principal place of abode as their spouse in the last 6 months of the year. The text chunk discusses the modification of the Abandoned Spouse Rule under Section 32(c)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for married individuals living apart with a qualifying child for more than half of the taxable year and not sharing the same principal place of abode as their spouse in the last 6 months of the year. It includes amendments to the code regarding the definition of marriage for tax purposes. The text chunk amends the rules for the presence of a qualifying child in the context of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It allows taxpayers to claim the credit for a worker without a qualifying child if the child is claimed by another family member. The text chunk states that if two or more eligible individuals may claim the same individual as a qualifying child, the one who claims the child is eligible for the tax credit, while the others are considered eligible individuals without a qualifying child. If an individual is claimed as a qualifying child by a parent, no other custodial parent without a claim can be considered eligible for the tax credit. Taxpayers are eligible for the credit if their qualifying children do not have valid claims. The amendment allows taxpayers to claim the tax credit for workers without qualifying children if their qualifying children do not have valid social security numbers. The amendments made by this section allow individuals without qualifying children to be eligible for the tax credit. Effective dates for these amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2014.
